New-York Historical Society
Cass Gilbert papers PR 21
380 Linear Feet (696 boxes, 444 bound volumes)
1883-1952 Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections The Cass Gilbert Collection contains the professional and personal papers of the architect Cass Gilbert. This includes information on his architectural projects, professional affliations, and personal business. This finding aid does not include information on his architectural drawings.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Gift of Cass Gilbert Jr. and Emily Gilbert, 1956 and 1957.
Access Restrictions
Open to qualified researchers.
Photocopying undertaken by staff only. Limited to thirty exposures of stable, unbound material per day. See guidelines in Print Room for details.
Use Restrictions
Permission to reproduce any Print Room holdings through publication must be obtained from:
Rights and ReproductionsThe New-York Historical Society
Two West 77th Street
New York, NY 10024
Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 282
Fax: (212) 579-8794
Preferred Citation
This collection should be cited as the Cass Gilbert Collection, PR 021, Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections, The New-York Historical Society.
Biographical Note
Cass Gilbert was born on November 24, 1859 in Zanesville, Ohio to Samuel Augustus Gilbert and Elizabeth Fulton Wheeler Gilbert. The family moved to St. Paul Minnesota in 1868, and in 1878 Gilbert went to study architecture at Massachusetts Institute of Technology. After traveling and studying in Europe, he joined the New York office of McKim, Mead & White in 1880. In 1882, he was sent to St. Paul to open a branch office for McKim, Mead & White and to oversee the building of depots, terminals, and hotels for the Northern Pacific Railroad. Within two years, the office collapsed and Gilbert formed a partnership with James Knox Taylor in St. Paul that lasted until 1892. Gilbert produced churches and houses in Minnesota and was a recognized architect when he won a competition to design the Minnesota State Capitol in 1895.
In 1899, Gilbert returned to New York City and received a number of significant commissions. He won a competition to design the United States Custom House (1901-1907) and designed the 24 storied building at 90 West Street (1905-1907) in Manhattan. From 1911-1913, Gilbert worked on the Woolworth Building. At 55 stories tall, it was the tallest building in the world from 1913 to 1930 and became one of Gilbert's most famous designs. Other buildings in New York designed by Gilbert include the New York Life Insurance Company Building (1925-1928) and the US Courthouse (1936), which was completed after his death. Gilbert also completed designs for the George Washington Memorial Bridge (1927-1931) that proved to be too expensive and were never used.
Gilbert also became known for his work on the Art Building in the Louisiana Purchase Exposition in 1904 which eventually became the St. Louis Art Museum. He also designed the St. Louis Public Library (1907-1912) and the Detroit Public Library (1913-1921). His work in Washington D.C. included the US Treasury Annex (1918-1919), the US Chamber of Commerce (1924-1925), and the US Supreme Court Building (1933-1935).
Gilbert was active in art and architectural organizations. He was appointed by President Theodore Roosevelt as chairman of the Council of Fine Arts. He was made a member of the Commission of Fine Arts by President Taft and reappointed to the post by President Woodrow Wilson. He was a long time member of the American Institute of Architects and served as its president from 1908-1909. In 1919 he resigned his membership from the AIA after disputes with the leadership of the organization. He was also a long time member of the National Academy of Design and served as its president from 1926-1932. He also served as a member of the National Institute of Arts and Letters.
Gilbert was recognized in America and abroad for his architectural work. He received honorary degrees from the University of Michigan, Oberlin College, and Middlebury College and was awarded the Society of Art and Sciences Gold Medal Award in 1930. In Europe, he was made an honorary member of the Agricultural Society of the University of Liverpool and an honorary foreign member of the Royal Academy of Arts. He was also decorated with the French Legion of Honor.
In 1887, Gilbert married Julia Tappan Finch, the daughter of a wealthy attorney from Milwaukee. Together they had three children: Cass Gilbert Jr., Emily Finch, and Julia Swift who became the wife of Charles Morgan Post. The family owned many properties including places in Manhattan and Connecticut. Gilbert was active in various social clubs including the Century Club and the Union Club. Gilbert died on vacation in Brockenhurst, England in 1934 at the age of 75. Cass Gilbert Jr. worked as an architect in his father's office and finished many of the office's projects after his death.
Scope and Content Note
The Cass Gilbert Collection spans the period from 1883-1952 (bulk 1900-1934) and contains professional and personal papers relating to the architect Cass Gilbert. This finding aid does not include information on the architectural drawings of Cass Gilbert. Most of this collection consists of files related to his numerous architectural projects. These files contain materials related to projects that he completed as well as projects that he worked on but did not complete. The collection also documents his extensive work in art and architectural associations. His personal papers mainly relate to personal business and some family letters are included. The arrangement attempts to adhere to Gilbert's filing system as closely as possible. See the Print Room at the New-York Historical Society for a detailed box and folder listing for the collection.
Arrangement
The collection is divided into nine series:
Missing Title
Series 1: Project Files
Series 2: Office Files
Series 3: Professional Organizations
Series 4: Personal Files
Series 5: Lantern Slides
Series 6: Record Book of Drawings
Series 7: Scrapbooks
Series 8: Metal Printing Plates
Series 9: European Sketchbooks
Related Material at the Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections
The Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections at the New-York Historical Society also holds the architectural drawings of many of Cass Gilbert's projects.
Photographs of many Cass Gilbert projects can be found in the Geographic File, PR20. A photograph of the dinner thrown by F.W. Woolworth in Cass Gilbert's honor can be found in the Portrait File, PR52, under Groups, Commercial, in Large Format. There is also a photograph of Cass Gilbert and his family in the Portrait File, PR 52, under "G" in Medium Format.

Series I. Project Files21738
Scope and Contents note
This series includes material related to Cass Gilbert's architectural projects. Most of the projects are buildings built by Gilbert. However the files also include information on projects he competed for but did not receive or are documents regarding a particular subject or a business. This series represents the bulk of the collection.Subseries I: Foldered Material21819
Scope and Contents note
This subseries contains the box and foldered material regarding Cass Gilbert projects. The material has been filed alphabetically by project and then by the project number assigned by Gilbert's office. Gilbert also designated material within the project files by type. Thus, the project files are also divided by type of material. The types of material include Preliminary Correspondence, Correspondence, Memoranda/Notes, Specifications, Bid Documents, Proposals, Reports, Contracts/Agreements, Financial Statements (includes Requisitions), Change Orders, Drawings, Photographs, etc.Abbott Apartment Building (Milwaukee, WI)2200418901Adams Stable (112 East 52nd Street, NY, NY)220031900-19101American Academy of Arts and Letters (New York, NY)220021928-19341-5American Insurance Company Building (Newark, NJ)220011902-19305-12American Terra Cotta and Ceramic Company22000190112Arkansas State Capitol (Little Rock, AR)219991901-193013-25Atlantic Refining Company (Philadelphia, PA)219981919-192026-30Austin Nichols & Company (Brooklyn, NY)219971913-193030-42Peter Bent Brigham Hospital21996191042Beverly Public Library (Beverley, MA)219951905-191942-44Brazer Building (Boston, MA)219941896, 190144Bridgeport Savings Bank (Bridgeport, CT)219931914-193445-50E.C. Scope and Contents note
This subseries contains all the volumes relating to Cass Gilbert's architectural projects. The volumes are mainly letterbooks containing outgoing copies of correspondence or books of specifications. Other volumes include records of contracts or financial ledgers. Many of these volumes are fragile and access is dependent upon the judgment of the print room staff. These photographs are not part of the original collection and were donated separately.Minnesota State Capitol- Newspaper Clippings Book217421903-1905682West Virginia State Capitol- Clippings Book217411920-1925683United States Supreme Court Building- Photographs of Building Models and Cabinet Sketches217401931684Series II. Office Files21668
Scope and Contents note
This series includes all administrative files relating to Gilbert's professional career and the running of his office. This includes information on his employees, the products and services used by the office, and the different office spaces inhabited by the architecture firm. The office files also document Gilbert's outside professional work such as serving as a judge for architecture competitions, advising on city planning, and his opposition to a plan to build a power plant in Washington D.C. Most of the files are designated #103.Subseries I: Correspondence21703
Scope and Contents note
The office correspondence is mostly incoming and any significant amounts of outgoing copies are filed separately. The letters are filed by date and then by correspondent. The general office correspondence consists of letters regarding potential projects, businesses promoting their products, and orders for supplies. Correspondence regarding workers consists of letters of introduction, men's letters asking for work, and a set of letters from office employees who want recommendations to serve in World War I. The correspondence also includes professional matters such as asking Cass Gilbert to speak at events or to judge architecture competitions. This subseries includes letters from Cass Gilbert Jr. if they relate to the business. Personal letters from Cass Gilbert, Jr. can be found in Series IV.Office Correspondence21737Undated, 1892-1900566Office Correspondence217361900-1902567Office Correspondence217351902-1903568Office Correspondence217341903-1905569Office Correspondence217331906-1907570Office Correspondence217321907-1908571Office Correspondence217311908-1909572Office Correspondence217301910-1911573Office Correspondence217291911574Office Correspondence217281911-1912575Office Correspondence217271912-1913576Office Correspondence217261913-1914577Office Correspondence217251914-1915578Office Correspondence217241915579Office Correspondence217231916580Office Correspondence217221916-1917581Office Correspondence217211917-1918582Office Correspondence217201918-1919583Office Correspondence217191919-1920584Office Correspondence217181920-1921585Office Correspondence217171921-1922586Office Correspondence217161922-1923587Office Correspondence217151923-1924588Office Correspondence217141924-1925589Office Correspondence217131925-1926590Office Correspondence217121926-1927591Office Correspondence217111927-1928592Office Correspondence217101928-1929593Office Correspondence217091929-1930594Office Correspondence217081930-1931595Office Correspondence217071931-1932596Office Correspondence217061932-1933597Office Correspondence217051933-1934598Office Correspondence217041934599Subseries II: Memoranda21701

Scope and Contents note
This subseries includes weekly calendars with space for a daily agenda. The calendars document his meetings, travel plans, and what he completed in the office for a particular day.Weekly Appointment Calendars216881914-1934607-608Subseries VII: Publications21685
Scope and Contents note
This subseries includes offers from various magazines for the publication of plans or for subscriptions to the magazine.Various Publications216861900-1907608Subseries VIII: Clippings21683
Scope and Contents note
The clippings in this subseries include articles related to the architectural projects of Gilbert's office or by other architects. The subseries also contains clippings regarding the proposed power plant in Washington D.C. and city plans for New York City.Clippings216841901-1931608Subseries IX: Other Material21681
Scope and Contents note
This subseries contains other office and professional files. It includes documents regarding the NYC Regional Plan, the Washington DC Power Plant Site, office spaces, office policies, employees, John Rockart vs. Cass Gilbert Inc., etc.Miscellaneous Office Files216821900-1937609-610Subseries X: Bound Volumes21673
Scope and Contents note
Most of the volumes are letterbooks that contain copies of outgoing letters from Gilbert's office. Other volumes include contract records, cash books, journals of expenses, records of work, payroll ledgers, and a transcript from James Stewart & Co. vs. US Claims Court. Many of these volumes are fragile and access is dependent upon the judgment of the print room staff.Letterbooks216801883-1937343-371Contract Records216791909-1937372Cash Books216781883-1934373-380Journals of Expenses216771903-1934381-383Records of Work216761891-1908384-385Payroll Ledger216751928-1935386Cass Gilbert Jr. Testimony for the Plaintiff in James Stewart & Co. vs. US Claims Court, Volume I216741942387Subseries XI: Oversize Materials21669
Scope and Contents note
The oversize materials include a brochure on the Hollar Company, a copy of Skyscrapers of New York by Vernon Howe Bailey, service sheets by the Architectural Service Corporation, and a photograph of the artists at the Columbian Exposition Building.Brochure on Hollar Company21672[1920]685Skyscrapers of New York by Vernon Howe Bailey with introduction by Cass Gilbert216711923685Service Sheets by the Architectural Service Corporation216701916-1919685Series III. Professional Organizations21621
Scope and Contents note
This series includes documents relating to Cass Gilbert's involvement in art and architectural organizations. Files relating to his participation in other organizations or causes are located within his personal files. The organizations most heavily represented are the American Institute of Architects, the Commission of Fine Arts, and the National Academy of Design.Subseries I. Foldered Material:21626
Scope and Contents note
Most of the subseries consists of correspondence but memoranda, reports and brochures are also included. The files regarding the American Institute of Architects include materials on the national organization as well as the state and local chapters. Bound Volumes21622
Scope and Contents note
This subseries contains four letterbooks of outgoing correspondence regarding the American Institute of Architects, the Commission of Fine Arts, and the National Academy of Design. Many of these volumes are fragile and access is dependent upon the judgment of the print room staff.American Institute of Architects-Letterbook216251907-1909388Commission of Fine Arts- Letterbook216241912-1918389National Academy of Design- Letterbook216231926-1934390-391Series IV. Personal Files21541
Scope and Contents note
This series includes Gilbert's files that do not reflect his architectural work or professional life. The material includes letters among his friends and family as well as important papers from his personal life.Subseries I: Correspondence21581
Scope and Contents note
This subseries consists of incoming letters to Cass Gilbert. The correspondence includes personal letters from family, friends, and colleagues relating to matters such as his insurance, the purchase and upkeep of his properties, automobile maintenance, and family finances. Many of the letters also document his donations to organizations such as anti-prohibition groups and patriotic organizations in World War I. Letters from his family include letters from his wife Julia Finch Gilbert, letters from his brother Samuel relating to Gilbert's insurance policies, and letters from his brother Charles related to property. Letters from other family members are included. Correspondence from colleagues includes letters from Edwin Blashfield, Alexander Calder, Daniel Chester French, F.H. Olmstead, Sir Aston Webb, etc. Some letters to Cass Gilbert from 1918-1919 relate to Cass Gilbert Jr.'s service in WWI. Incoming correspondence to other family members is also included. These include many sympathy letters to the Gilbert family after the death of Cass in 1934.Correspondence (to Cass Gilbert)21620Undated, 1887-1902633Correspondence (to Cass This subseries contains organizational materials documenting Gilbert's work with groups including the Carnegie Institute,the Louis Comfort Tiffany Foundation, and the Parks and Playgrounds Association. This subseries contains invitations to events from friends and organizations. Included are invitations to the White House by Presidents Theodore Roosevelt and Herbert Hoover. This subseries contains issues of publications regarding Gilbert's personal interests.Publications saved by Cass Gilbert215481920-1934674Subseries XII: Other21545
Scope and Contents note
This subseries contains folders of personal materials that do not fit in with the above subseries. It includes passports of Cass Gilbert, papers regarding family genealogy, and his written memories of important events.Other Family Papers215461911-1934674Subseries XIII: Bound Volumes21542
Scope and Contents note
This subseries contains letterbooks of personal outgoing correspondence. Topics include expenses, residences, his work on World War I committees, etc. One book contains letters regarding Cass Gilbert, Jr's work with the American Society of the French Legion of Honor. Many of these volumes are fragile and access is dependent upon the judgment of the print room staff.Letterbooks215441889-1937392-430Letterbook, American Society of the French Legion of Honor (Cass Gilbert, Jr.)215431934-1935431Series V. Lantern Slides21527
Scope and Contents note
The lantern slides include glass slides of some of Cass Gilbert's projects as well as studies of other buildings around the world. The slides are divided into two subseries that reflect Gilbert's numbering of the slides. It appears that the two groups of slides were used for two separate purposes.Subseries I: Woolworth Building21539
Scope and Contents note
This subseries of lantern slides depicts only the Woolworth Building. The images include exteriors and interiors as well as depictions of construction and the finished building. Most of these images are also represented in the photographs in the Woolworth Building section of the Project Files series.Lantern Slides of the Woolworth Building215401910-1913675-676Subseries II: National and International Cites21528
Scope and Contents note
This subseries of lantern slides depicts all types of architecture from all over the world including bridges, fountains, parks, museums, and villas. Although a few of Gilbert's projects are represented in this subseries (St. Louis Art Museum, Belle Isle Bridge) most of the slides are not of his work. The slides represent architecture in the United States as well as in France, Italy, England, Holland, Spain, Japan, and Germany.France21538Undated677-678United States21537Undated, 1916678-679Italy21536Undated679-680England21535Undated680Holland21534Undated680Spain21533Undated680Japan21532Undated680Germany21531Undated680Miscellaneous21530Undated680Panoramic Slide of New York Central Park21529Undated680Subseries III: Glass plate negatives73336US Custom House, plaster model of Genoa73337680AGeorge Washington Bridge, Perspective drawing, John T. The record books contain lists of drawings issued and received by Cass Gilbert.
